posts.name: Eren
posts.cooked: Hello. I am part of a Turkish FIRST Robotics Competition team. While in the U.S., I purchased an Orange Pi 5 Plus 8GB model from Amazon for my team. Upon receiving it, I realized I had ordered the Ultra 8GB model instead, which is available on the Orange Pi website. I feel slightly inconvenienced because the Ultra model is slightly cheaper and comes with support from PhotonVision. However, I noticed that there are no images available on PhotonVision's GitHub repository for the 5 Plus Ultra model. This raises concerns about its compatibility. Ideally, I would like to return the Orange Pi at a nearby Whole Foods store for a refund, but I'm unsure whether the price difference between the two models will be refunded. Given these uncertainties, I'm hesitant to keep the device and wonder if such a refund is feasible.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked: I would read this. It has what's compatible with Photonvision. PhotonVision is a free, fast, and easy-to-use vision processing solution for the FIRST Robotics Competition. It's used for testing future systems for vision, though the orange pi was once the standard now it’s not anymore. I'm not sure why.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Eren
posts.cooked: It falls under the category of 'non-supported devices' which should still support PhotonVision fine. I guess it's just not ideal. Install the latest image of PhotonVision for your coprocessor: For the supported coprocessors-RPi 3,4,5, Orange Pi 5, 5B, 5 Pro, Limelight 2, 2+, 3, 3G... For installing on non-supported devices, visit https://docs.photonvision.org/en/latest/docs/quick-start/quick-install.html.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked: When discussing the system requirements for a project involving vision processing, it became evident that the hardware specifications must meet certain criteria. These include using Ubuntu 22.04 LTS or Windows 10/11, ensuring sufficient RAM and storage, and having compatible IO ports. Specifically, a CPU capable of handling an ARM Cortex-A53, at least 8GB of storage, and 2GB of RAM were deemed essential. Additionally, the system must utilize the Raspberry Pi 3's MIPI-CSI port for camera connectivity, noting that other ports may not function properly. While the discussion initially highlighted OrangePi, further analysis revealed its absence in recent documentation, focusing instead on the effectiveness of PhotonVision under these configurations.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Matthew L
posts.cooked: This is still the case we just want to encourage people to stick with the base Pi 5 model instead of the Ultra Pro or Plus versions. Quick question why is the orange Pi 5+ not officially recommended On the NPU part of the docs it says it is supported I have also had great results testing it and it is not that much more expensive while offering more USB ports and better performance.

posts.name: Graham Howard
posts.cooked: I assume because it’s more expensive and doesn’t actually have better performance for Photon (it’s the same SOC).

posts.name: Matthew L
posts.cooked: The SOC is different, rk3588 on 5+ versus rk3588 S on 5, and it exhibits slightly enhanced performance according to online benchmarks.

posts.name: Graham Howard
posts.cooked: As far as I know, they're identical compute-wise, just with slightly different peripherals.

posts.name: Matthew L
posts.cooked: Oh ok, that makes sense. Our team just bought 5+'s to test multiple cameras with the extra USB port and see if there are any performance improvements or reductions. It was only about $30 CAD (~$21.90 USD) more, so it’s not a big deal if there’s no performance improvement.

posts.name: Craig Schardt
posts.cooked:
As someone who has maintained and tested the PhotonVision images for the past few years, I am happy to share additional details about the Orange Pi 5. This powerful Single Board Computer (SBC) is based on the RK3588(S) processor, featuring an 8-core CPU comprised of four A55 and four A76 cores. It also includes a built-in Neural Processing Unit (NPU) for machine learning tasks, unlike other SBCs that require an add-on NPU. This configuration makes it highly suitable for PhotonVision, excelling in both April Tag recognition and machine learning-based object detection due to its robust processing capabilities.

The base Orange Pi 5 model, equipped with 4GB of RAM, contains everything needed to run PhotonVision effectively. Developers commonly use this version for testing, as it provides sufficient performance without requiring additional hardware. While there are variations such as the Plus, Max, Pro, B, and Ultra models, these differences are negligible for running PhotonVision, making the base board the most reliable choice.

Upgrading to a more expensive variant or adding more RAM does not enhance PhotonVision's performance. As noted by another contributor, the RK3588 and RK3588S models share identical CPU configurations, rendering any upgrade unnecessary for this application. Running PhotonVision and its operating system consumes less than 1GB of RAM, and increasing memory beyond this level does not yield better results.

When considering additional cameras, USB 2.0 connections may impose limitations on performance when multiple cameras are used simultaneously. To circumvent this, users can reduce resolution and frame rates or switch to USB 3.0 cameras. However, doing so may restrict CPU performance, particularly for April Tag detection on high-resolution images. Practical testing shows that over 30 frames per second (fps) can be achieved with two 720p cameras on one unit.

PhotonVision images are based on the Ubuntu-rockchip community project images, which powers the board. Currently, there is no official source available for the OPi 5 Ultra model, leading contributors to question the utility of providing images for various board variants. These differences necessitate additional effort for contributors and create potential confusion for teams utilizing PhotonVision. Consequently, the focus remains on supporting existing board models rather than introducing new ones.

For those interested in installing PhotonVision on other RockChip-based systems, detailed instructions are available, including support for boards like the OPi 5 Ultra. By using the provided install script, users can extend PhotonVision's capabilities beyond the base model.

In summary, while theOrange Pi 5 offers excellent performance for PhotonVision, additional considerations must be taken when selecting components and managing resources.

link_counts.title: Other Debian-Based Co-Processor Installation - PhotonVision Docs
GitHub - Joshua-Riek/ubuntu-rockchip: Ubuntu for Rockchip RK35XX Devices
